comments:
I started getting SWT error messages from eclipse all of a sudden. I am not sure
what triggered it. Some times it happens when i resized a pane ( by moving the
splitter divider ).

Below is the log file text.

I should have searched bugzilla first. It looks like this bug is a dupe of 81661
& 82012

May be this may help. I just realized it started happening after i fired up the
javadoc help by hitting F1 on JList.

This is not a duplicate of either of those bugs.  The error "no more handles" is
a generic error which means you are out of operating system resources.  It
generally means that something in your application is buggy, and is not cleaning
up after some operations.

Do you have any additional plugins installed?  How large is your workspace?  Is
there anything strange about your setup that you can think of?

I killed the Help window and the problems went away.

I have the following plugins installed:
Rational Clearcase 6.0.42
Antlr
EPIC
Jar Search

No more SWT errors and no more stacktraces. Does the help window embed a browser
(IE)?

The Help window does embed a browser.

We need to see if we can reproduce the problem.  Christophe, have you ever 
seen this side effect with the Browser?

It looks like the user's system is simply running out of OS resources - maybe 
because some of the plugins leak them. 

On my own notebook with little memory, I often run out of memory when trying 
to bring up the Help system in addition to the existing eclipse.


MD:
- if you restart the machine, start eclipse and press F1 to bring up the help -
 does it fail?
- how much RAM do you have?
- do you have similar problems with a default eclipse? Just in case one of the 
extra plugin is the one leaking image resources and triggering the problem.
I have 2GB RAM on a Quad 2GHz Xeon running Win2k3.
I get the error when I have the javadoc view, even with all plugins disabled.

If a plugin is leaking or using too many system resources, there's not much 
that SWT can do.

Apparently the problem is happening in the javadoc view - we could run SLeak 
and bring up javadoc view and see if we notice any major leaks.
